metadata.title: An investigation on the lubrication mechanism of MoS2 nano sheet in point contact_ the manner of particle entering the contact area

sections.text:
The goal of the work is to investigate the lubrication mechanism of MoS2 nano
sheet. Polyisobutyleneamine Succinimide (PIBS) provides the steric repulsion to disperse nanoparticles in oil due to its long carbon chain. In the present study, the tribological behavior of nano-MoS2 sheet mixed with different percentages of PIBS was explored. The dispersed state and the mode of nano-MoS2 sheet entering the contact point were studied. Ball-on-disk results illustrated that the COF of nano-MoS2 in paraffin oil with free of PIBS was 26.2 % compared with those containing 3 wt% PIBS, and the reduction of wear depth reached 41.9 %. The nano-MoS2 sheets with 3 wt% PIBS were in discrete state in paraffin oil, which moved with side flow and

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano particles are novel lubricant additives. Over the past few decades, the
effect of nano particles as lubricant additives on friction and wear behaviors has been widely investigated [1-6]. Their efficacy for tribological applications was demonstrated [2, 7-9]. Furthermore, many hypotheses to explain the lubrication mechanism of nano particles, typically like the ball bearing effect [1, 10-12], depositing film [13, 14], and self-repairing effect [15], etc., have been proposed, as shown in Fig. 1(a).
However, results of some tribological studies demonstrated that not all types of
the nanoparitlces exhibited anti-friction and anti-wear behaviors. Aralihalli’s result [16] indicated no friction coefficient reduction for nano particle in oil containing PIBS in a ball-on-disc sliding test. Rabaso et al. [7] showed that there was not any effect on the tribological behavior of the formulated commercial lubricant after adding of IF-MoS2 nano particles. IF-MoS2 nano particles in base oil did not affect the friction coefficient when dispersant (PIBS) was used. Reversely, the nano particles in a PAO base oil without any dispersant provided outstanding friction and wear reduction capacities. It was thought that the presence of succinimide-based dispersant (PIBS) prevented the occurrence of tribochemical reactions between the nano particles and the steel surfaces, leading to the absence of tribofilm adhesion. Ref. [17] illustrated that the tribological behavior of MoS2 nano particles modified with γ-APS was significantly influenced by the concentration of PIBS. They anticipated that the existence of PIBS prevented the physical adsorption of the modified nano particles,
and subsequently reduced the amount of nano particles entering the contact area. In addition, according to [8], the avoidance of any competition for the additive to adhere/adsorb/react on the lubricated metal surface requires (i) the selection of very low polarity base oil (such as PAOs), and (ii) the absence of surfactant/dispersant to stabilize or promote the dispersions of nanoparticle additives. However, those anticipations seemed lacking of supportive evidence to substantiate.
Furthermore, findings in some existing literatures seemed inconsistent and even
contradictive to each other. Typically, study of Kogovsek et al, [18] suggested that the tribological performance of particles are largely determined by their material, insignificantly influenced by their morphology (shape), and even less significantly affected by the particle size. However, finding of Lovell et al. [19] indicated that the 20 nm nanoscale boric acid powder-based lubricants tended to give lower wear rate than that of larger sized boric acid (600 nm, 4 μm) additive-based lubricants, which seemed to imply size of particles significantly influencing their lubrication performance.
There are, in fact, many issues remaining unknown in nano particle lubrication.
Generally, improving the anti-friction and anti-wear performance of base oil using nano particles is easy, while enhancing the lubrication performance of formulated oil [7], like gear oil and engine oil, is difficult. Lubrication properties of nano particles in any formulated lubricant need to be thoroughly assessed and analyzed. Moreover, whether can the nanoparticles in the oil around the friction pairs enter into the contact area? If the nanoparticles in the oil cannot enter into the contact area, the nanoparticles may not have advantages, as shown in Fig. 1(b). Identification of factors, like the mode and the amount of particles entering the contact area, are also paramount important. Typically, the issue of how shape and size of nano particle benefit in achieving the anti-friction and anti-wear performance is still not known. As research to clarify such mechanisms allows suitable application of nano particle additives in gears, rolling bearings and engines, it should be very interesting and helpful if the crucial mechanism involved in the mode of nano particles entering the contact area is properly revealed.
Direct visual observation of the particle flow in a tribological system is a useful
method to acquire knowledge of how particles entering into contact region. Yang and Schmid [20, 21] demonstrated the important role played by oil droplet flow in oil-in-water emulsion lubrication. Their results suggested that all the oil particles would be rejected from the contact region if the inter-particle collisions were ignored. Sliney et al. [22-24] firstly used in situ video to study solid lubricants (graphite, MoS2) during a friction test. The useful technique facilitated understanding of particle movements inside the contact area, and subsequently used to explain the difference in tribological behaviors in friction test lubricated by MoS2 or graphite. In the present study, MoS2 nano sheet was selected as the nanoparticle additive due to its advantages of nanoscale thickness and visible in the microscope.
The objective of this research is to reveal the lubrication mechanism of MoS2
nano sheets. It begins with investigating the tribological behavior of modified nano sheets with different PIBS concentration on a tester of ball on steel disk system. It then simulates the sliding on a ball on glass plate system with a microscope to observe the different moving behavior of MoS2 particles with various PIBS percentages around the ball contact area. The observation allows the effect of particle dispersion state and flowing behavior on the lubrication performance to be anticipated and/or correlated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation and characterization of nano sheets
sections.text:
Commercially available MoS2 nano sheets with width of 2-3 μm were selected
(obtained from Beijing Dk Nano technology Co., Ltd, China), which can ensure the MoS2 nano sheet flow could be observed in the microscope. Commercially available ZDDP (Zinc dialkyldithiophosphates) and PIBS were used in the present work. Liquid paraffin with viscosity of 17.2 mm 2 /s at 40 o C and 3.44 mm 2 /s at 100 o C was chosen as base oil in the experiments.
ZDDP were applied as surfactant to modify the nano sheets in the present study.
The nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution in this study was prepared by: (i) adding 0.05 wt% of ZDDP into 20 g paraffin oil, which was followed by 10 min mixing in an ultrasonic bath; and (ii) subsequently dispersing 1 wt% MoS2 nano sheets into the ultrasonic bath which was vibrating for 30 min. For the study of the influence of PIBS on the lubrication performance of nano-MoS2-ZDDP, PIBS of 0.05 wt%, 0.1 wt%, 0.3 wt%, 0.5 wt%, 1 wt% and 3 wt%, respectively, were correspondingly added to the oil containing nano sheets and sonicated for 10 min.
The SEM analysis was conducted on a JEOL JSM-6460LV equipment which is
also embedded with EDS for composition analysis. A JEOL JEM-2100 TEM operating at 200 kV accelerating voltage was employed to acquire the morphology of the particles.

sections.heading: 2.2. Friction test and wear analysis with different PIBS
sections.text:
concentration
The friction reduction and anti-wear properties of the nanolubricants were
evaluated using a ball-on-disk reciprocating tester (UMT-2, CETR Corporation Ltd., USA). Commercially available AISI52100 bearing steel balls having hardness of 63.8 ± 0.9 HRC and 9.5 mm in diameter were used in the tester. TheΦ30 mm×5 mm thick 1045 steel disks having hardness of Hv200 and surface roughness of 0.020 μm were used as test specimens. Tests to characterize the tribological behaviors under boundary lubrication regime [25] were conducted with loading of 30 N, sliding velocity of 0.036 m/s, and reciprocating linear stroke of 6 mm in ambient air.
Profile of wear scars on the slid disk was scanned by a TR200 profiler, made by
Time Group Inc., China. Worn surface morphology was analyzed by JEOL JSM-6460LV SEM. Atomic force microscopy (AFM, Innova, Veeco) was applied to evaluate the surface topography of disk samples in the scanned area of 10×10 to 50 ×50 µm 2 .

sections.heading: 2.3. Observation of the manner of particle entering into the
sections.text:
contact area
A special experimental setup similar to reciprocating testing (Fig. 2) was applied to obtain real-time observation of the particle moving behavior around the contact. A 1 mm thickness glass disk was firstly pasted with a drop of prepared in-used nano oil solution, which was mounted to press (about 1 N) and slid on a 9.5 mm diameter AISI52100 steel ball to form contact area. A system with a WH300 microscope was used to focus on the ball surface and record the relevant images to a personal computer. During the test, the steel ball was fixed and the glass disk was being moved reciprocally with a stroke length of 6 mm. The frequency was different than those chosen for the tribological testing in order to ensure the obtainment of an adequate resolution for the exploitable images. Results of such tests and those of tribological studies permitted to correlate and understand the influence of the moving behavior of nano sheets with the formation mechanisms of tribofilm.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of MoS2 nano sheet
sections.text:
The SEM map and EDS analytical spectrum of the original MoS2 particles are
shown in Fig. 3. It shows MoS2 particles to be composed of many nano sheets. It gives thickness of nano sheet to be below 100 nm (Fig. 3(a)), which was much smaller than its width. EDS spectra (Fig. 3(b)) suggests the presence of Mo and S (elements from MoS2), and the element of O only.
The TEM images (Fig. 4) shows MoS2 sheets to be irregular. Most regions of the
sheets (Fig. 4 (a) and (b)) are transparent and the structures with nano-thickness are flaky.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of PIBS concentration on the tribological
sections.text:
behavior
The influence of PIBS concentration on the COF of nano-MoS2-ZDDP is shown
in Fig. 5. Trend with nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution free of PIBS (Fig. 5 (a)) revealed the lowest friction coefficient (about 0.09), which assumed a 35.3 % reduction in friction coefficient when compared with that of base oil (0.139). However, the COF increased to 0.10, 0.115, 0.12 and 0.122 with the adding of 0.05 wt%, 0.3 wt%, 1 % and 3 wt% PIBS, respectively, in the correspondingly in-used nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution. Moreover, the COF of all the lubricants containing nano-MoS2-ZDDP were generally lower than that of mere paraffin oil and that of the lubricant without adding of any MoS2 nano sheets (about 0.139). Such comparison clearly revealed the effectiveness of anti-friction property of nano-MoS2 sheet. Furthermore, the average COF of nano-MoS2-ZDDP solutions (Fig. 5 (b)) increased with the increase in PIBS percentage which was in the range of 0.05 wt% to 3 wt% in this study. Analysis of Fig. 5 (b) suggested that the most sensitive percentage of PIBS to create sharp change in average COF was from 0.05 wt% (which was most effective in reducing COF) to 0.5 wt%.
Variation of cross-sectional profiles across the steel wear scar under the action of
in-used nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution with different PIBS percentages is illustrated in
smooth and only mild wear was observed under the nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution without PIBS (Fig. 7(a)), while the mode of obvious plowing wear was identified on the steel surface lubricated by the nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution with 3% PIBS (Fig. 7(c)). Moreover, EDS results in Table 1 illustrates the formation of MoS2 tribofilm on the wear scar of disk in the case of nano-MoS2-ZDDP without PIBS. In addition, Fig. 7(b) revealed relatively milder plowing wear appearing on the steel surface under the nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution with 0.05% PIBS in comparing with that under its counterpart solution with 3% PIBS. The analyses seemed to be consistently agreeable with the friction reduction curve in Fig. 5(b).
Results in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 showed that the tribological behavior under the
action of nano-MoS2-ZDDP solution was significantly affected by PIBS concentration. Such interesting tribological behavior seemed hard to be explained by the “micro-rolling bearing” mechanism [17]. Although the assumptions that PIBS preventing MoS2 nano sheets physically adsorbing on the steel surface [7, 17] could be possible explanation, those assumptions have not been confirmed experimently and hence required further investigation. Studies to explore the lubrication mechanism of nano sheet additives are surely worthwhile to perform so that the influence of PIBS concentration on the tribological behavior of MoS2 nano sheets can be relatively clearly explained.
To further explore the lubrication mechanism of MoS2 nano sheets, the tribofilm
formations of nano-MoS2-ZDDP without PIBS and 3 wt% PIBS were evaluated by comparing surface morphology using AFM, as shown in Fig. 8. The wear tracks in the case of free of PIBS (Fig. 8(a)) show smoother surfaces compared with that of 3 wt% PIBS in Fig. 8 (b). Moreover, AFM results in Fig. 8(a) revealed that large amount particles embedded on the surface when lubricated with nano-MoS2-ZDDP free of PIBS. However, Fig. 8 (b) shows the obvious plowing wear when lubricated with nano-MoS2-ZDDP containing 3 wt% PIBS. In addition, the fine MoS2 particles could not be found by AFM on the worn surface in the case of 3 wt% PIBS. The AFM results in Fig. 8 confirm that the amount of MoS2 forming the tribofilm were different. It also suggests that the amount of MoS2 particles forming the tribofilm in the case of
without PIBS was much larger than that of nano oil containing 3 wt% PIBS.

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanism analysis of different tribological
sections.text:
performance
To explore the mechanism of different amount MoS2 sheet forming the tribofilm,
directly observing the flow behavior of MoS2 sheets around the contact area was conducted with a microscope in the setup as shown in Fig. 2. The observation aims at exploring the mode of particles entering the contact area and subsequently correlating the influence on their lubrication properties.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Aggregation and tribofilm formation progress with 0.05 wt%
sections.text:
PIBS
Fig. 9 shows the progression of how the formation of MoS2 tribofilm was in the
case of 0.05 wt% PIBS. Initially, not much MoS2 sheet was accumulating in the front of the contact region with a particle aggregation zone part (Fig. 9(a)). However, an aggregation was observed to move to the contact area by the fluid entrainment of disk surface. Those aggregated particles piled up in the front of the contact region when the flow of aggregation arrived at the contact area, as shown in Fig. 9 (b). As sliding of glass was proceeding, another particle aggregation to move to the contact area was observed (Fig. 9 (b)). As shown in Fig. 9 (c), the accumulated particles in front of the contact region were penetrating into the contact area to form a tribofilm. Analysis of the microscopic photos in Fig. 9 revealed that the particles from the aggregation were the source of MoS2 tribofilm, and its formation enhanced the anti-friction and anti-wear performance of base oil.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Mechanism of poor lubrication properties with 3 wt% PIBS
sections.text:
Screen captures of the particle flow mode in case of 3 wt% PIBS in point contact
via a PC connected to the microscope were shown in Fig. 10. Flow traces suggested almost all the particles having tendency to follow streamline (as shown by the arrows in Fig. 10 (a)) bypassing the contact. As a result, most of the particles were found to escape the contact zone as side flow instead of entering the contact. Fig. 10 (b) reveals the gradient distribution of the particles in the inlet region. About 250 μm apart from the contact area, the particle distribution becomes much denser than that near the contact area. Furthermore, particle was completely absent near the contact area. The observation of flow patterns in Fig. 10 suggested the rejection of particles from the contact inlet by sideway flowing of fluid. As a result, the base oil was unable to enhance its anti-wear and anti-friction performance of base oil.
On the basis of the aforementioned observations, the lubrication mechanism of
nano sheet in both low and high PIBS concentration can be envisaged as illustrated in Fig. 12 and Fig. 13.
In low PIBS percentage, the capping layer density was relatively small and the
nano sheets tended to aggregate due to the van der Waals' force, as shown in Fig. 11 (a). In this case, (i) the particle aggregations entrained by the disk surface moved to the contact area (Fig. 12 (a)); (ii) the particle aggregations flowed to accumulate in front of the contact area (Fig. 12 (b)); (iii) those particles in (ii) were then dragged into the contact area by reciprocating disk (Fig. 12 (c)); and (iv) a well-distributed MoS2 tribofilm was formed under the contact and extrusion, showed in Fig. 12 (d).
However, particles are the discrete state in the case of high PIBS concentration
(3 wt% in the present study). In this case, the particles capping with long carbon chain (PIBS) provided the steric stabilization to prevent aggregation [26, 27], as shown in Fig. 11 (b). Moreover, the discrete particles moved around the contact area due to the side flow in point contact, showed in Fig. 13 (a). Therefore, the discrete state nano sheets could not enter the contact area in the case of high PIBS concentration, which tended to reveal poor tribological performance (Fig. 13 (b)).
Based on the above analysis, the tribological behavior of nano sheets in paraffin
oil was significantly influenced by their dispersed condition. The nano sheet aggregation beneficially enhanced the tribological performance of the oil. The dispersed state and spreading characteristics of spherical nanoparticle on the influence of its lubrication performance were interesting and deserved further investigations.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
(1) The tribological properties of nano-MoS2-ZDDP were affected by PIBS
concentration. The friction coefficient reduction of nano-MoS2-ZDDP without any PIBS reached 35.3 % compared with paraffin oil, while it was only 12.2 % in the case of with 3 wt% PIBS. The wear volume loss of nano-MoS2-ZDDP with 3 wt% PIBS was much larger than that of nano-MoS2-ZDDP without any PIBS.
(2) SEM and AFM analyses showed much smoother surface when lubricated
with nano-MoS2-ZDDP with low percentage PIBS, while it showed plowing wear in the case of nano-MoS2-ZDDP with 3 wt% PIBS.
(3) The dispersion condition of nano-MoS2-ZDDP was influenced by PIBS
concentration within the solution. In the case of low PIBS percentage and without any PIBS, formation of nano sheet aggregations was observed. However, the particles seemed to be spread in discrete state in the case of mixing high percentage of PIBS.
(4) The different tribological properties of nano sheets with different PIBS
percentage are attributed to the particles dispersion state and spreading in the lubricant in relation to the contact area. The lubrication mechanism of nano sheet with different PIBS concentration in the present study was anticipated below:
(a) In the case of low PIBS percentage and without any PIBS, the nano sheet
aggregations accumulated in front of the contact area tended to enter the contact area and form a well-distributed tribofilm within the contact region. Those aggregations were beneficial in reducing COF and wear loss.
(b) When lubricated with high percentage of PIBS, the discrete particles tended
to move and spread around/away from the contact area due to the effect of side flow, hence the particles could not enter the contact area and resulted in poor lubrication properties.
